Line.Text: (A little corridor leads to the exit from your room and the spacious hallways of LIFE+ headquarters, all but deserted at this hour. From there, you can go back up to the lobby where you were before the dinner.)
(Go back to the lobby)
(Stay here for the moment)
(The bed looks simple yet comfortable and, like all inviting beds, seems to be silently asking you one question: is it time to sleep yet?)
(Is it time to sleep yet?)
Yeah, let’s wrap it up for the day.
Nah, it’s early. The night is young.
Probably, but when did it ever stop us?
Just one more video, mom!
The bed was mocking me, the same “you will regret it in the morning” I’d heard a hundred times before.
For once, I had to admit defeat and embrace its comfort.
But my references were spinning out of control, and I had to see this through.
I'd filled my head with so much information it was starting to feel cramped.
Better to consolidate it with sleep than keep piling things up.
One should never underestimate one’s own limits.
Guilt had ambushed me once again. I never saw her coming.
I had to work on my detection skills, and for that, I needed rest.
Then we browsed together for a while, and she saw the error of her ways.
Here I was again, using the internet that wasn’t mine for reasons I didn’t fully understand.
It was time to pull the plug.
But I’d come too far to close the session now.
I wasn't the man I used to be in the morning.
Hitting refresh was the only option.
Then again, nobody is in this ever-changing world.
This was my sentence. To keep looking at the bed until it was too late to get well-rested.
A few hours are still better than none.
But I was long past regretting it.
Why do we sleep? Science still hasn’t found an answer to this question.
And so we end the day shrouded by yet another mystery.
Then let’s wait until it does!

Did you know that human is the only mammal who willingly delays sleep? Apparently, none of our evolutionary relatives are into this whole “just a few more minutes and then I’m going to bed for sure” stuff.
What a nice way to feel closer to nature.
It’s their loss.
Drowsiness is no laughing matter. Can you imagine how many road accidents could’ve been prevented if only people weren’t falling asleep behind the wheel?
I, for one, care about the safety of my fellow human beings.
That, or we can just invent self-driving cars. Boosh, problem solved!

Our complex relationship with sleep is often reflected in our culture. In Japan, dozing off during corporate meetings is viewed as a sign of diligently working long hours and considered not only excusable but sometimes commendable.
I’m no competition for the old-school salarymen.
I’ll be one hell of a dedicated worker tomorrow.

Your dreaming may be affected by the type of entertainment you experienced as a child. It is said that the black-and-white TV generation used to have monochrome dreams, while today most people dream in color.
I wonder what my gaming-fueled brain will show me tonight.
Surely the most dream-affecting technology is yet to come.
What if our dreams are not just dreams but entire worlds that exist only until we wake up?
Careful with that recursive train of thought, buddy; you’ll get stack overflow.
Yeah, I don’t feel like being a mass murderer today.
Is it time to sleep yet?
Yeah, might as well.
Not even close.
Is it time to sleep yet?
Is it time to sleep yet?
Is it time to sleep yet?
Not quite.
